hints.content:
An $\blueE{\text{even}}$ number is a number that can be split into $2$ equal groups.

We find $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers by making sure every object in the group has a pair.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d50cd961bb1ee962eb60cc708a5e737e9d4486c)

Examples of $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers are $\blueE2, \blueE4,\blueE6, \blueE8, \blueE{10},  . .  .$

An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

We find $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers by trying to pair objects and finding there is **not** always a pair.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/10c3af09ebfcd0c6d05b4edd219f33894cc4d8b9)

Examples of $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers are $\maroonD1, \maroonD3, \maroonD5, \maroonD7, \maroonD9, . . . $

In this image, there are $\maroonD{11}$ elephants.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/106946bc448f1a5caf6047075debe3f40a484a9f)

Each elephant does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of elephants.

In this image, there are $\maroonD9$ cows.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/60f37c168aac92f36b5947f1f2c5ecc976e60cea)

Each cow does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of cows.

In this image, there are $\blueE{14}$ dogs.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/eeb03a3f8479af51dabacd657b47570c1b3c6f75)

Each dog has a pair, so there are an even number of dogs.

Here is the completed table:

Image | Even/Odd
- | - | -
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/b1a78c9fe346f9dc10db197f2f8bf0fb53136b82) | **Odd**
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/1ef1cf939fae3e5327b2d1a94b586f75188021a7) | **Odd**
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/3bd055e4f48c4d5e3b6c4b95e0a1605d7e98d9ee)  |  **Even**

question.content:
**Determine whether the number of objects is even or odd.**

- | - | -
